results.title: Voyage a travers l'impossible
results.brief_description: Across mountains, under the sea and into the sun, a group of strange travellers attempt an impossible voyage. Exploiting Melies’ mastery of film magic, this early cinema classic explores a vast range of fantasy landscapes. The travellers breach space and time as they travel, using every imaginable means of transportation, from one space and place to another in the attempt to geographically explore the earth and the surrounding space. This extraordinary science fiction fantasy was only one of the many pioneering films made by Melies in the early 1900s and it, like his other films, combines whimsical humour with wild imaginative journeys.

results.title: Journey to the centre of a triangle (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Katharine Cornwell, Bruce Cornwell and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Examines the incentre, circumcentre, the centroid, and the orthocentre of triangles. Visual constructions illustrate each kind of centre, and several examples are used to show how each is determined. Without narration. For beginning geometry students.

results.title: Dihedral kaleidoscopes (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Art Landy, University of Minnesota and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Presents basic ideas of symmetry by exhibiting dihedral groups by reflections of intersecting mirrors. From reflection in a single mirror the film proceeds to study the surprising effects and beautiful patterns that can be produced with two or three mirrors. Observations on the general case are made as well as on the limiting case in which two mirrors are parallel.

results.title: Orthogonal projection (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jay Hines, Don Gangloff, Art Landy, Allen Downs and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces an elementary transformation involving triangles transformed into a problem involving conics. Uses certain fundamental geometric notions such as division of line segments into given ratios, in variance under transformations, conic sections etc. which are encountered in other parts of geometry.

results.title: Inversion (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jay Hines, Seymour Schuster, College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Geometric inversion is introduced and discussed to effect the solution of an apparently difficult problem involving the inscription of a chain of circles between two given circles, one inside the other. The final result, known as Steiner’s Porism, is forcefully illustrated in motion - “pop art” fashion.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jay Hines, Seymour Schuster, College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota and International Film Bureau

results.title: Projective generation of conics (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Introduces the eccentricity definition, then focuses on projective definitions devoid of metric notion implying the construction of a conic by straight edge alone. Shows methods of construction developed by Pascal, Malaurin, Braikenridge, Poncelet and Steiner. The logical relationship between the methods is demonstrated.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Allen Downs, Bob Nelson and College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Uses computer-generated animation in order to illustrate the Whitney-Graustein theorem - two regular curves in the plane are regularly homotopic if, and only if, they have the same rotation number.

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Computer animation records the deformation of regular closed curves and the rotation of tangent vectors and demonstrates the theorem that two regular curves in the plane which are regularly homotopic must have the same rotation number. Concludes with a concrete problem and a challenge to explore the converse of the theorem as discussed in part 2.
